channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Israel Attacks Iran’s Nuclear Sites, Kills Senior Commanders
item.description: Israel launched strikes across Iran on Friday morning, targeting nuclear facilities and killing top military commanders in a major escalation against its chief adversary that risks sparking a broad war in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Marissa Newman, Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: First-responders gather outside a building that was hit by an Israeli strike in Tehran on June 13, 2025. Israel hit about 100 targets in Iran on June 13, including nuclear facilities and military command centres and killing senior figures including the armed forces chief and top nuclear scientists. (Photo by MEGHDAD MADADI / TASNIM NEWS / AFP) (Photo by MEGHDAD MADADI/TASNIM NEWS/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: US to Ease Rules Hindering Tesla’s Self-Driving Cybercab
item.description: The Trump administration is taking steps that would make it easier for automakers to deploy-self driving cars without driver controls, a potential boon to the ambitions of Tesla Inc. and rivals looking to put robotaxis on US roads in the near future.
item.dc:creator: Keith Laing

media:content.media:description: Tesla's self-driving electric Cybercab.

item.title: Dutch Cabinet Approves NATO’s 5% Defense Spending Target
item.description: Dutch Prime Minister Dick Schoof’s caretaker cabinet agreed to increase defense and security spending to 5% of gross domestic product by 2032 in line with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s proposed target.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: People wait in line at the Binnenhof in The Hague.

item.title: Four Men Escape From ICE-Contracted Detention Facility in Newark
item.description: Four people detained by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement escaped from a privately operated detention facility in Newark, New Jersey, a senior Homeland Security official told Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: Delaney Hall Detention Facility in Newark, New Jersey.

item.title: Starmer Signals Support for 3.5% NATO Aim With Talks on Date
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer indicated that the UK was prepared to endorse a new NATO target committing 3.5% of members’ economic output to core defense spending, although he emphasized that key details such as the timeline were still being negotiated.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: United Kingdom soldiers storm an enemy position in a simulated attack during the NATO military exercise in Drawsko Pomorskie, Poland.

item.title: Germany’s Klingbeil to Support Push to End EU Capital-Markets Impasse
item.description: German Finance Minister and Vice Chancellor Lars Klingbeil said he’ll support a push to try to break a deadlock on a decade-old European Union effort to deepen the bloc’s capital markets.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Rauwald, Isolde MacDonogh

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil, Germany's finance minister, at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, on Friday, June 13, 2025. Germany's economy is facing a third year without growth as businesses struggle with uncertainty around global trade, according to the Bundesbank.

item.title: US, Vietnam Near Trade Framework as Tariff Deadline Approaches
item.description: The US and Vietnam are closing in on a framework trade agreement, despite ongoing concerns about Chinese goods being rerouted through the Southeast Asian nation to avoid tariffs, according to people familiar with the talks.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen

media:content.media:description: Workers iron items of clothing at a garment factory in Binh Thuan province, Vietnam.

item.title: NY Lawmakers Near Deadline to Pass Bill Targeting Emerging Market ‘Vulture Funds’
item.description: New York state lawmakers are within days of a deadline to pass legislation targeting so-called vulture funds that has languished in the local legislature for the past two years.
item.dc:creator: Zijia Song

media:content.media:description: The New York State Capitol in Albany.

item.title: Battle Over Sports Betting Threatens Lula’s New Fiscal Plan
item.description: A fierce lobbying push by sports betting companies is threatening to bring down the Brazilian government’s plan to raise revenues and hit fiscal goals after the lower house speaker backed off support for a deal he helped broker.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: Oil Tanker Market Roiled by Israeli Airstrikes Against Iran
item.description: Israel’s overnight airstrikes on Iran drove up freight rates and tanker stocks Friday as traders and investors priced in the prospect of disruption to a large swath of the global oil-shipping fleet.
item.dc:creator: Weilun Soon, Alaric Nightingale

item.title: Key Iran Nuclear Enrichment Site of Natanz Shows No Sign of Breach
item.description: The United Nations atomic watchdog said there’s no indication of increased radiation levels at Iran’s main uranium-enrichment site, an early sign that Israel’s strikes haven’t penetrated the containment layers protecting the Islamic Republic’s nuclear stockpile.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: The Natanz nuclear facility in Iran in January.

item.title: Keir Starmer Says UK Is Luring Top Talent Even as Non-Doms Leave
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said he wants to attract more investors to Britain, even as the nation contends with an exodus of wealthy individuals because of tax hikes.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Stupples, Alex Wickham, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer speaks with tech apprentices at Downing Street in London.

item.title: India and Canada Reach Deal to Share Intelligence on Terrorism, Crime
item.description: The governments of Canada and India are set to establish a new structure to share information about cross-border crimes, their latest step toward rebuilding ties nearly two years after Canadian officials accused India of orchestrating the murder of a Sikh activist near Vancouver.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister, during a news conference in February.

item.title: Starmer Says UK Has ‘Grave Concerns’ on Iran Nuclear Program
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the UK has “grave concerns” about Iran’s nuclear program and backed Israel’s right to self-defense, while calling for de-escalation in a conflict that risks engulfing the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Alex Wickham, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer in London, on June 13. Photographer: Tom Skipp/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Wants to Make It More Expensive to Sue Over His Policies
item.description: President Donald Trump and his allies are pursuing an alternative strategy to defend against mounting court orders blocking his policies: Raise the financial stakes for those suing the administration.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump signs an executive order in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Trump on Friday signed orders meant to accelerate the construction of nuclear power plants, including small, untested designs that offer the promise of rapid deployment but have yet to be built in the US.

item.title: Switzerland’s Government Approves Contentious EU Deal
item.description: The Swiss government approved the country’s new bilateral deal with the European Union, which was hammered out late last year after long negotiations with the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Jan-Henrik Foerster

media:content.media:description: A Swiss national flag ahead of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Sunday, Jan. 19, 2025. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 20 to 24. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer Says No Obstacles Left in Finishing US-UK Trade Deal
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said there are no “hiccups or obstacles” remaining in the way of finalizing a trade deal with the US and indicated that an agreement would likely come soon.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Alex Wickham, Mishal Husain

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers and dockside cranes at London Gateway port, operated by DP World Plc, in Stanford-le-Hope, UK, on Monday, Oct. 7, 2024. DP World spent £300 million ($366 million) on a fourth berth at its London Gateway container hub.

item.title: Trump Plans Biofuel Quota Boost, Seeks to Crimp Imports
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing oil refiners blend more biofuels into gasoline and diesel next year while seeking to discourage the use of imported supplies.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Kim Chipman

media:content.media:description: A Phillips 66 renewable fuels refinery in Rodeo, California.

item.title: Trump Administration Orders 500,000 Immigrants to Leave US
item.description: Immigrants admitted to the US from a Biden-era parole program for Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Venezuela have begun receiving notices of termination urging them to depart the US.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kreighbaum

media:content.media:description: Department of Homeland Security Police officers at San Francisco International Airport (SFO) in San Francisco, California, US, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Flyers heading out for the Memorial Day holiday in the US are bracing for stress as record numbers of travelers place fresh strain on an outmoded and undermanned air traffic system.

item.title: Trump’s Orders Delay CFTC Effort to Get Out of $21 Million Lease
item.description: Even before Donald Trump retook the White House and Elon Musk’s DOGE fanned out across government, the CFTC was on board with reducing its real estate footprint, saving taxpayers millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Beyoud, Gregory Korte, Natalie Wong

media:content.media:description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission headquarters currently costs $21 million in annual rent. Its new space will cost $6 million but won’t be ready before mid-2026.

item.title: Everyone Is Watching Donald Trump: G-7 Leaders Guide
item.description: Mark Carney will welcome world leaders to the Canadian Rockies hoping to avoid a repeat of the blow up the last time his country played host

item.title: Spain’s Government Braces for Legal Clash on BBVA’s Sabadell Bid
item.description: The Spanish government is preparing for a court battle over its opposition to BBVA SA’s takeover bid for smaller lender Banco Sabadell SA, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Jorge Zuloaga

media:content.media:description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria SA Photographer: Angel Navarrete/Bloomberg

item.title: Netherlands, Sweden Push for Sanctions Against Israeli Ministers
item.description: Sweden and the Netherlands are pressing the European Union to sanction members of the Israeli cabinet over the war in Gaza, joining several other nations in the region whose stance on Israel has hardened in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini, Samy Adghirni, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the West Bank on June 11.

item.title: Greek IPTO Seeks Pay for Delays to €1.9 Billion Subsea Cable
item.description: Greek grid operator IPTO SA is seeking compensation for delays to getting licenses for seabed surveys that are needed to complete what’s set to be one of the world’s largest power links.
item.dc:creator: Paul Tugwell

media:content.media:description: Manousos Manousakis Source: IPTO

item.title: Trump Can Keep Deploying Troops in LA for Now, Court Says
item.description: The Trump administration won a brief reprieve from a judge’s order to pull back on its use of military troops in Los Angeles to deal with protests over the president’s immigration raids.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: National Guard soldiers outside the Edward R. Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles on June 8. Photographer: Kyle Grillot/Bloomberg

item.title: China Security Office Flexes New Power With Hong Kong Probe
item.description: Beijing’s national security office in Hong Kong carried out its first known joint operation with city officials, marking an expansion of China’s direct law enforcement in the financial hub.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong

media:content.media:description: Protestors wave flags outside the Commissioner's Office of China's Foreign Ministry in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, June 29, 2020. The national security law that China could impose on Hong Kong as early as this week won't need to be used if the financial hub's residents avoid crossing certain "red lines," according to Bernard Chan, a top adviser to Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: Bangladesh’s Yunus Signals February Vote After Political Talks
item.description: Bangladesh’s interim leader Muhammad Yunus has indicated that a national election could take place as early as the week before Ramadan begins in February, should reforms advance sufficiently in the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Muhammad Yunus, a Nobel Peace Prize-winning economist, speaks during an interview at his residence in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Wednesday, May 1, 2024. In August, Yunus is scheduled to go on trial for a money-laundering case, which carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.

item.title: India Open to Easing EV Rules as China’s Rare Earth Curbs Bite
item.description: India is amenable to relaxing the 50% localization it expects from electric vehicle makers and suppliers in return for incentives, after China’s curbs on rare earths exports put the goal in doubt, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Sachdev

media:content.media:description: Rare earth magnets

item.title: Japan’s Kato Says Talks With Markets Key for Bond Issuance
item.description: Japan’s Finance Minister said that discussions with market participants is a key factor in making sure that government bonds are bought and sold stably, as the ministry neared a closely watched gathering with investors.
item.dc:creator: Shery Ahn, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Katsunobu Kato Photographer: Shoko Takayasu/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea Agrees to Cut Indonesia Share in Fighter Jet Project
item.description: Indonesian and South Korean officials have signed a revised deal that significantly lowers Jakarta’s financial commitment to the joint KF-21 fighter jet program, a move aimed at reviving long-stalled progress on the multibillion-dollar project.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: A KF-21 fighter jet model at the Responsible AI in the Military Domain summit in Seoul on Sept. 10.
